Things to do After a Car Accident

Each and every year, countless people are involved in traffic accidents. If you're one of those unfortunate people, will you understand how to proceed in the aftermath of a collision? How you react can prevent additional injuries, reduce costs and increase the clean-up and repair process. Over 6.3 million police-reported automobile crashes occurred in the United States in 1998. Almost 1/3 of these accidents led to injuries. In 2001, nearly 42,000 people died on America's roadways. Clearly,accidents are a part of life in the states. So, if you are involved in a traffic collision, try to stay calm, and follow these steps:

1. Keep anEmergency Kit in your glove compartment. Drivers should carry a cell phone, in addition toa pen and paper to take notes, a disposable camera to take photos of the vehicles at the scene, and a card with information about medical allergies or problems that may require special attention if there are severe injuries. Also, keep a list of contact numbersfor lawenforcement agencies handy.

2. Keep basic safety first. Individuals involved in minor accidents with no serious injuries should movecars to the side of the street and out of the way of oncoming traffic. Leaving cars and trucks parked in the center of the road or busy intersection can lead to more incidents and injuries. If a car can't be moved, drivers and passengers should stay in the cars with seatbelts attached for everyone's safety until ems arrives. Ensure that you turn on hazard lights and set out cones, flaresor caution triangles if you can.

3. Swap information. After the automobile accident, exchange the following information: name, address, telephone number, insurance company, policy number, driver license number and license platenumber for the motorist and the owner of each car or truck. If the driver's name differs from the name of the insured, establish exactly what the relationship is and write down the name and address for each individual. Alsomake a written description of each and every car, including the year, make, model and color - as well as the exact place of the collision and how it happened. Finally, be courteous but don't tell the other drivers or the police that the accident was your fault,even if you think it was.

4. Photograph and document the accident. Use your throw away camera todocument the damage to all the motor vehicles. Keep in mind that you would like your photos to show the overall context of theaccident to be able to make your case to anadjuster. If there were witnesses, try to get their contact information; they may be able to help you if the other drivers dispute your version of what took place.
